Why did Zhangzhou peasants travel southwards?

context: <a1_0><b6_0><b11_0>Xiamen dialect<b11_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/>, sometimes known as <a0_0><b10_0>Amoy<b10_0/><a0_0/>, is the main dialect spoken in the Chinese city of Xiamen and its surrounding regions of Tong'an and Xiang'an, both of which are now included in <b7_0>the Greater Xiamen area<b7_0/>. This dialect developed <b8_0>in the <a2_0>late <b5_0>Ming dynasty<b8_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> when <a3_0>Xiamen<a3_0/> was increasingly taking over Quanzhou's position as the main port of trade in southeastern China. Quanzhou traders began travelling southwards to Xiamen <b14_0>to carry on their businesses<b14_0/> while <b9_0>Zhangzhou peasants<b9_0/> began traveling northwards to Xiamen <a4_0>in search of job opportunities<a4_0/>. It is at this time when a need for a common language arose. The Quanzhou and Zhangzhou varieties are similar in many ways (as can be seen from the common place of Henan Luoyang where they originated), but due to differences in accents, communication can be a problem. Quanzhou businessmen considered <b12_0>their speech<b12_0/> to be the prestige accent and considered Zhangzhou's to be a village dialect. Over the centuries, <b13_0>dialect leveling occurred<b13_0/> and the two speeches mixed to produce the Amoy dialect.
